bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 26, 1941

div1.p: Hench is thrilled to have the Reed contract and appreciates the Agramonte and Sternberg letters. He notes that soon he will be able to see the correspondence between the Yellow Fever Board and the Surgeon General. He mentions that Kissinger had had a stroke.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 26, 1941
div1.opener:
Reed June30
1941
Aus July 5-
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
June 26, 1941
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I cannot adequately express my appreciation of your continued generosity
to me. You have been so extremely helpful and kind. For a long time I haven't
had a thrill like that which I had when the contract arrived. I have proudly
showed it to many of my colleagues already. Temporarily, it is in my library,
but shortly will be exhibited in the library of the Mayo Clinic. I realize that
this is one of the finest souvenirs you have of your own military medical exper-
iences and to think that you would give it to me makes me feel very humble and
grateful.

I certainly want to thank you also for the very interesting Agramonte
and Sternberg letters. They will be extremely useful and will be carefully pre-
served with all of my material. Having continued my search, I have just heard
from Mr. R. H. Brooke, Chief Clerk, Office of the Surgeon General, that the corres-
pondence between the Yellow Fever Board and the Surgeon General and his office
will be available for me the next time I come to Washington. It is stored in
Fort Myers, Virginia, and I am delighted to know of it because I suspect that there
will be much data of extreme importance, particularly some which will help us get
the accurate dates of various activities and among other things prove the movements
of the various members of the Board.

I have just had a letter from Miss Laura Wood. Doubtless, she is the
Vassar lady whom you spoke about. I see no reason why her efforts and mine should not
be coordinated. Certainly her book for children will not interfere with mine, and
if you say so, I will let her have copies of much of the material that I have re-
ceived. May I remind you that a couple of the letters of Reed that you loaned
me had rather confidential information in them. One spoke very scathingly of the
medical men at Pinar del Rio; another spoke disparagingly of the editors of the
A.M.A. Do you wish me to give her copies of all the letters of Reed that you
have sent me or shall I be selective and send her only those which I would think
proper and helpful for her? One of the best collections of Reed's letters available
for her is the collection of Mrs. Blossom Reed. She showed it to me. It contains
most of the letters which she and her mother received from Reed over a period of
many years, some of them being to Mrs. Reed even before she and Reed were engaged.
This collection is very illustrative of his character and his activities. Unfor-
tunately, it is incomplete when it comes to the yellow fever investigation as
apparently Mrs. Reed did not keep copies of these letters which she gave away. Mrs.
Blossom Reed permitted me to take some notes from these letters but of course I
cannot let Miss Wood have them myself but will refer her to Mrs. Reed.

I return
these letters
herewith.
They are
most interesting
& extremely
valuable.

You asked me to institute myself as “the guardian” of the Yellow Fever
Roll of Honor. I shall be only too proud to accept this responsibility. However,
I don't quite know how the attempts to get on the Roll of Honor could be called
General J. R. Kean
- 2-
June 26, 1941
to my attention. Is there someone in Washington who would notify me of these
attempts? I shall be only too glad to go to bat at any time before any senatorial
or house committee, and keep the story straight. Thanks to the great generosity
of yourself and others, I do think I have that story pretty straight, and I
heartily agree with you that it is a terrible thing for outsiders to try to get
on this Roll through political machinery. I assume that Lambert's claim was
turned down as was that of Poucher. Lambert used to be a very good friend of
Moran's during his Cuba days. But Moran told me confidentially a rather unhappy
story of Lambert's activities in Panama. It seems that there was some dishonesty
connected with Lambert's actions when he and Moran were in charge of pharmaceutical
supplies for the army. Thereafter, Lambert and Moran parted company.

I am returning your copy of the Chronology and an extra copy which I
had made for you, thinking that this would save you from sending your own out on
some future occasion to someone else.

I believe I told you that Kissinger had a stroke. Mrs. Kissinger says
that he is quite a nursing problem, as she has no help and has a very bad backache
herself. Apparently, he is completely paralyzed on one side, has difficulty in
speaking and also in vision. It occurred to me that if he is to be a nursing
problem until his death, which may not be for some months or even years, the best
solution for all concerned would be to have him admitted to a veterans' hospital
or a general army hospital. I have not suggested this to Mrs. Kissinger, but
I am trying to find the name of their physician to size up the situation before
making any suggestions whatever. I do not want to get too mixed up in this but cer-
tainly hope I can be helpful. What do you think of this suggestion? Assuming
that he can be moved by train or plane, would he be admissable to Walter Reed
Hospital or a veterans' hospital? I imagine the family physician would be very
glad to transfer the medical responsibility because doubtless Kissinger is able
to pay very little to his doctor.

Permit me to enclose a couple of photographs of yourself and General
Ireland, and one of the hospital where you told me Walter Reed died. I am sending
a copy to General Ireland.

I have Mr. Hagedorn's address and hope that I can get in touch with him
about some information.

Just this morning a friend of Mrs. Blossom Reed wrote me that she (Blossom)
was stricken last Sunday with a “severe cardiac attack” & may be
confined to bed for “several months.” This is the second tragic aftermath
of an happy Cleveland affair! Hope I'm not next!!
